issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fixVersions.description: The release will stabilize core components, improve performances and adds new streaming algorithms. Unmaintained code is getting killed as part of this

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

versions.description: The release will stabilize core components, improve performances and adds new streaming algorithms. Unmaintained code is getting killed as part of this

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Cleanup Vector Benchmarks make it less variable

author.name: jake.mannix
author.emailAddress: jake dot mannix at gmail dot com

comments.body:
"as you can see..."

It looks like SASV is still 5x faster than RASV for DotProduct, or am I not reading the right result?

updateAuthor.name: jake.mannix
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jake dot mannix at gmail dot com

author.name: jake.mannix
author.emailAddress: jake dot mannix at gmail dot com

comments.body: Ah, yes, nevermind, comparing 2nd to 3rd columns.  What are the sizes for this test (num nonzeroes and cardinality) ?

updateAuthor.name: jake.mannix
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jake dot mannix at gmail dot com

author.name: jake.mannix
author.emailAddress: jake dot mannix at gmail dot com

comments.body:
Ok, so I'm trying to wrap my head around _how_ RASV could ever get nearly as fast as SASV for dot products (or vector sums, for that matter).  Is it because the load factor we use in OpenIntDoubleHashMap is 1.2, and so the overall number of nonzeroes is roughly the same as the size of the backing arrays, and the only slowdown OIDHM has over OrderedIntDoubleMapping is that the former needs to quickly check the states array to verify it's in state FULL?

Numbers don't lie, unless they come from microbenchmarks, in which case they tell... "selective truths" shall we say.

updateAuthor.name: jake.mannix
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jake dot mannix at gmail dot com

comments.body:
http://xkcd.com/1131/

Load factor is one thing,I think it has more to deal with the processor cache.
  Total Number of Cores:	4
  L2 Cache (per Core):	256 KB
  L3 Cache:	6 MB

I will refactor the benchmark further to run multiple sparsities (10k:1k, 100k:1k, 1M:1k, 10M:1k) and report back.

The previous result was 100k:1k (cardinality:non-zeros)
This is (1M:1k)
